title: How do we smell? - Rose Eveleth

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the nasal cavity is used to filter air before it hits the lungs?

Conceptual Question: What is the significance of the size of the olfactory epithelium in determining an animal's sense of smell?

options.label: A
options.text: A larger olfactory epithelium indicates a weaker sense of smell.

options.label: B
options.text: A larger olfactory epithelium indicates a stronger sense of smell.

options.label: C
options.text: The size of the olfactory epithelium has no relation to an animal's sense of smell.

options.label: D
options.text: A smaller olfactory epithelium indicates a more sensitive sense of smell.

multiple-choice.question: Application Question: If a person has a condition where they cannot smell anything, how might it affect their sense of taste?

options.label: A
options.text: They will be able to taste more flavors.

options.label: B
options.text: They will be able to taste only sweet and salty flavors.

options.label: C
options.text: They will not be able to taste anything more complicated than the five basic tastes.

options.label: D
options.text: They will not be affected in any way.

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question: What can be inferred about the relationship between smell and memory based on the fact that smell signals are processed in various regions of the brain, including the amygdala?

options.label: A
options.text: Smell has no relation to memory.

options.label: B
options.text: Smell can trigger memories, but only emotional ones.

options.label: C
options.text: Smell can trigger memories, including emotional and non-emotional ones.

options.label: D
options.text: Smell is only related to short-term memory.

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question: What is the name of the chemical that smells like vanilla to some people and sweaty urine to others?
Conceptual Question: Why is it that people with anosmia, or the inability to smell, may also experience a reduced sense of taste?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the sense of taste is entirely dependent on the sense of smell.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the sense of smell plays a significant role in detecting flavors beyond the five basic tastes.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the brain processes smell and taste signals in the same region.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the olfactory epithelium is responsible for both smell and taste.

options.text: Because they are often used as symbols of wealth

options.label: D

title: Planning for the end of oil - Richard Sears

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason oil is a convenient starting place for a discussion about energy?

options.text: It is a widely available resource.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a very energy-dense liquid that can be easily refined into useful products and fuels.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the most environmentally friendly energy source.

options.label: A
options.text: Peak oil, followed by a decline in energy use

options.label: B
options.text: Peak gas, followed by a rise in renewable energy

options.label: C
options.text: Peak renewables, followed by a decline in energy use

options.label: A
options.text: They are made of different materials

options.label: C
options.text: They are the same material, but with different molecular structures

title: My glacier cave discoveries - Eddy Cartaya

multiple-choice.question: What type of rock are most caves in the eastern part of the country made of?

What happens to the snow on Mount Hood as it accumulates over time?

options.label: B
options.text: It gets crushed into hard, blue ice

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which new tunnels form in glacier caves?

options.label: A
options.text: Melting of ice by warm air from below

options.label: B
options.text: Freezing of water by cold air from above

options.label: C
options.text: Erosion of ice by rivers of water on the surface

multiple-choice.question: How do cave explorers map a cave?

options.label: B
options.text: By using a laser to measure distances and a compass to measure direction

options.label: C
options.text: By drawing a map by hand as they explore the cave

options.label: D
options.text: By using GPS coordinates to create a map

What is the name of the cave that was discovered first?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was located at a higher elevation

options.label: B
options.text: Because it had a moulin that allowed cold air to flow in

options.label: C
options.text: Because it was located on the north side of the mountain

options.label: D

options.label: C

Who is credited with creating the first synthetic polymer, Bakelite?
What is the name of the polymer that was invented by accident during World War II and is known for its bouncy properties?
What is a potential environmental concern associated with the use of Styrofoam?

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: Why do plastics created by addition polymerization reactions, such as Styrofoam and plastic bags, pose an environmental problem?

options.label: C

title: How to sequence the human genome - Mark J. Kiel

multiple-choice.question: What is a genome?

options.label: A
options.text: A collection of cells that make up an organism

options.label: B
options.text: A collection of genes plus some extra that make up an organism

options.label: C
options.text: A collection of tissues that cooperate with each other

options.label: D
options.text: A collection of organs that cooperate with each other

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of genome sequencing?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand how cells interact with each other

options.label: B
options.text: To understand how tissues cooperate with each other

options.label: C
options.text: To know the sequence of letters that make up an organism's genome

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how organs cooperate with each other

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists increase the signal they can detect from each individual letter of DNA?

options.label: A
options.text: By using enzymes to break down the DNA into smaller pieces

options.label: B
options.text: By using enzymes to make thousands of copies of each genome piece

options.label: C
options.text: By adding special colored letters to the genome

options.label: D
options.text: By taking pictures of each snippet of genome

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of adding special colored letters to the genome?

options.label: A
options.text: To break down the DNA into smaller pieces

options.label: B
options.text: To make thousands of copies of each genome piece

options.label: C
options.text: To allow scientists to read the sequence of letters

options.label: D
options.text: To stitch together the sequences of each genome piece

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists stitch together the sequences of each genome piece?
What does the sequence of an organism's genome determine?

options.label: A
options.text: How cells interact with each other

options.label: B
options.text: How tissues cooperate with each other

options.label: C
options.text: How organs cooperate with each other

options.label: D
options.text: The characteristics of an organism, such as how they look and act

multiple-choice.question: Why is interpreting the genes of the genome important?

options.label: A
options.text: So we can understand how cells interact with each other

options.label: B
options.text: So we can understand how tissues cooperate with each other

options.label: C
options.text: So we can understand how the differences in our genomes account for differences in how we look, act, and respond to medicines

options.label: D
options.text: So we can stitch together the sequences of each genome piece

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential impact of better understanding the disparities between our genomes?

options.label: A
options.text: It will change the way we think about how cells interact with each other

options.label: B
options.text: It will change the way we think about how tissues cooperate with each other

options.label: C
options.text: It will change the way we think about how doctors treat their patients and how we treat each other

options.label: D
options.text: It will change the way we think about how organs cooperate with each other

multiple-choice.question: How long did it take to complete the first human genome sequence?

options.label: B
options.text: Less than the cost of a pretty nice birthday present

options.label: C
options.text: The same as the cost of a car

options.label: D
options.text: The same as the cost of a house

title: High-altitude wind energy from kites! - Saul Griffith

multiple-choice.question: What was George Pocock's contribution to the history of kites in 1827?

options.label: B
options.text: He pioneered the use of kites for towing buggies in races against horse carriages.

options.label: C
options.text: He developed the control systems for powered human flight.

options.label: D
options.text: He wrote a seminal paper on using kites to generate electricity.

options.label: B
options.text: It is more efficient than solar power.

options.label: C
options.text: It can be used at lower altitudes.

options.label: D
options.text: It is less expensive than traditional wind turbines.

options.label: A
options.text: Developing the control systems for powered human flight.

options.label: B
options.text: Generating enough electricity to power a household.

options.label: C
options.text: Building a kite that could fly at high altitudes.

options.label: D
options.text: Creating a kite that could carry heavy weights.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It could provide a significant portion of the world's energy needs.

options.label: D
options.text: It could solve the global energy crisis.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message of the transcript regarding the use of kites to generate electricity?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a new and untested technology with many challenges to overcome.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a promising technology that could provide a significant amount of clean energy.

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: What makes us feel good about our work? - Dan Ariely

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question: What was the result of the experiment where people were asked to build Bionicles for a decreasing amount of money in the "meaningful" and "Sisyphus" conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: People built more Bionicles in the Sisyphus condition.

options.label: B
options.text: People built more Bionicles in the meaningful condition.

options.label: C
options.text: People built the same number of Bionicles in both conditions.

options.label: D
options.text: People built fewer Bionicles in the meaningful condition.

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question: What is the concept of "meaning" in the context of labor and work, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Meaning is solely related to the amount of money earned.

options.label: B
options.text: Meaning is related to the sense of purpose and fulfillment derived from work.

options.label: C
options.text: Meaning is only relevant in creative fields.

options.label: D
options.text: Meaning is not important in the labor market.

multiple-choice.question: Application Question: How can the concept of "meaning" be applied to a workplace to increase employee motivation and productivity?

options.label: A
options.text: By providing more bonuses and incentives.

options.label: B
options.text: By giving employees more autonomy and ownership over their work.

options.label: C
options.text: By ignoring employee feedback and suggestions.

options.label: D
options.text: By reducing the workload and responsibilities.

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question: What is the relationship between the "Ikea effect" and the concept of meaning in labor and work?

options.label: A
options.text: The Ikea effect is unrelated to the concept of meaning.

options.label: B
options.text: The Ikea effect suggests that people value things more when they have put effort into creating them.

options.label: C
options.text: The Ikea effect only applies to consumer goods.

options.label: D
options.text: The Ikea effect is a negative phenomenon.

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question: What was the result of the experiment where people were asked to find pairs of letters on a sheet of paper and were either acknowledged, ignored, or had their work shredded?

options.label: A
options.text: People worked harder in the shredded condition.

options.label: B
options.text: People worked harder in the acknowledged condition.

options.label: C
options.text: People worked equally hard in all conditions.

options.label: D
options.text: People worked less hard in the ignored condition.

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question: What is the concept of "alienation of labor" according to Karl Marx?

options.label: A
options.text: The alienation of labor refers to the separation of workers from their work.

options.label: B
options.text: The alienation of labor refers to the lack of efficiency in production.

options.label: C
options.text: The alienation of labor is a positive phenomenon.

options.label: D
options.text: The alienation of labor only applies to manual labor.

multiple-choice.question: Application Question: How can a manager or leader increase employee motivation and productivity in a knowledge economy?

options.label: A
options.text: By focusing solely on efficiency and productivity.

options.label: B
options.text: By providing more autonomy, ownership, and meaning to employees.

options.label: C
options.text: By reducing employee responsibilities and workload.

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring employee feedback and suggestions.

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question: What is the relationship between the Industrial Revolution and the concept of meaning in labor and work?

options.label: A
options.text: The Industrial Revolution made meaning more important in labor and work.

options.label: B
options.text: The Industrial Revolution made efficiency more important than meaning in labor and work.

options.label: C
options.text: The Industrial Revolution had no impact on the concept of meaning in labor and work.

options.label: D
options.text: The Industrial Revolution only affected manual labor.

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question: What was the result of the experiment where people were asked to build origami and were either given easy or hard instructions?

options.label: A
options.text: People valued the origami more when they had easy instructions.

options.label: B
options.text: People valued the origami more when they had hard instructions.

options.label: C
options.text: People valued the origami equally in both conditions.

options.label: D
options.text: People did not value the origami at all.

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question: What is the concept of "pride" in the context of labor and work, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Pride is solely related to the amount of money earned.

options.label: B
options.text: Pride is related to the sense of accomplishment and fulfillment derived from work.

options.label: C
options.text: Pride is only relevant in creative fields.

options.label: D
options.text: Pride is not important in the labor market.

title: Mysteries of vernacular: Odd - Jessica Oreck and Rachael Teel

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the modern word "odd"?
In Old Norse, what was the original meaning of the word "oddi"?

options.label: D
options.text: A geometric shape with four sides

multiple-choice.question: What characteristic of a triangle led to the evolution of the word "oddi" to mean something unpaired?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of four right angles

options.label: B
options.text: The existence of two paired angles and a third that stood alone

options.label: C
options.text: The fact that it was a two-dimensional shape

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of three equal sides

multiple-choice.question: What did "odda mathr" refer to in Old Norse?

options.label: C
options.text: The odd man whose vote could break a tie

options.label: D
options.text: A geometric shape with three sides

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following meanings of "odd" was NOT borrowed by the English from Old Norse?

options.label: D
options.text: The notion of the odd man out

multiple-choice.question: In what century did the modern meaning of "odd" as "peculiar" emerge?
What was the inspiration behind the creation of the word "oddi" in Old Norse?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea of a horizontal object

options.label: C
options.text: The idea of a vertical-pointed object

multiple-choice.question: How did the meaning of "oddi" evolve over time in Old Norse?

options.label: A
options.text: It remained the same, referring only to a triangle

options.label: B
options.text: It came to mean any number divisible by two

options.label: C
options.text: It began to refer to something that wasn't matched or paired

options.label: D
options.text: It referred to a geometric shape with four sides

multiple-choice.question: What was the term used in Old Norse to describe an unpaired man whose vote could break a tie?
What is the connection between the Indo-European root "uzdho" and the modern word "odd"?

options.label: C
options.text: The root "uzdho" is unrelated to the modern word "odd"

title: Mysteries of vernacular: Yankee - Jessica Oreck and Rachael Teel

multiple-choice.question: What is the possible origin of the word "Yankee"?

options.label: B
options.text: From the Dutch moniker Janke, meaning little Jan or little John

options.label: C
options.text: From a New England city name

multiple-choice.question: In the 17th century, what group of people commonly used the nickname "Janke"?
How did the term "Yankee" initially transform over time?

options.label: A
options.text: From a general term to a pirate's nickname

options.label: B
options.text: From a pirate's nickname to a general term of contempt

options.label: C
options.text: From a New England term to a general American term

options.label: D
options.text: From a positive term to a neutral term

multiple-choice.question: Who used "Yankee" as a pejorative term for colonists in 1758?
By the 1780s, what did the term "Yankee" come to mean?
How did the colonists respond to the term "Yankee" during the Revolution?

options.label: A
options.text: They rejected it as an insult

options.label: B
options.text: They co-opted it and transformed it into a mark of national honor

options.label: D
options.text: They used it to mock the British

multiple-choice.question: What event intensified the derisive definition of "Yankee"?
How is the term "Yankee" perceived today?

options.label: C
options.text: As a neutral term, unless in the context of baseball

options.label: D
options.text: As a term only used in New England

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the Dutch pirate ship that operated in the West Indies?
Which of the following is an example of how the meaning of "Yankee" has changed over time?

options.label: A
options.text: From a positive term to a negative term

options.label: B
options.text: From a general term to a specific term

options.label: C
options.text: From a pirate's nickname to a general term of contempt to a mark of national honor

options.label: D
options.text: From a New England term to a general American term

title: Mysteries of vernacular: Lady - Jessica Oreck and Rachael Teel

multiple-choice.question: What is the Old English word that referred to a loaf of bread and is the direct ancestor of the modern word "loaf"?
What is the root of the modern word "dairy"?
What is the literal meaning of the Old English word "hlafdige"?

options.label: B
options.text: Loaf maid or kneader of bread

multiple-choice.question: What was the Old English word for a male head of household?
What is the process by which the words "hlafweard" and "hlafdige" lost their internal sounds to become "lord" and "lady"?
What was the original social standing associated with the title "lady"?
How has the usage of the word "lady" changed over time?

options.label: B
options.text: It has become less formal and is now often used to mean simply a woman

options.label: D
options.text: It has become more commonly used to refer to men

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the words "hlafweard" and "warden"?

options.label: C
options.text: "Warden" is derived from the same root as "hlafweard"

multiple-choice.question: What was the role of the "hlafdige" in a household?

options.label: B
options.text: Mistress of servants or female head of the household

multiple-choice.question: In what century did the word "hlafdige" become a title of respect?
